title: Why isn't The Wheel of Time respected in the literary world? Why didn't it win any awards ever? - Quora

response.answer_text: Robert Jordan built an incredible world, with an intriguing history, full of diverse characters, populations, terrains. Sometimes his books resemble travalogues so real does the landscape seem - even the passage of time for the various voyages/trips are realistic. Also, his overall story arc is interesting, including all the side stories and flashbacks to the past. HOWEVER!!! His characters never really evolve. We are TOLD they do, but we don’t see it. There are some really ridiculous stupidities (the spanking - I’m sorry????). The idea that powerful women who can wield magic would somehow ignore all known patterns of feminine group behavior and create a hierarchy based purely on who the most powerful magic user is? WTF, Jordan! That’s ridiculous! Plus, Jordan’s actual writing style isn’t the best. I sped thru these books because I wanted very much to see what happened - ergo, great plot. I cared about the characters even tho they weren’t exactly gaining much maturity. But when I went back to re-read, after knowing what would happen? Couldn’t do it, sadly. I prefer Brandon Sanderson as a writer. When Robert Jordan died Sanderson was picked by Jordan’s widow to finish the series, and so with Jordan’s notes Sanderson did so. He’s done a superb job of it and we therefor have Robert Jordan’s complete vision intact :D Thank goodness! BTW, it’s been picked up for a mini-series which I think could be amazing!

… Because the “literary world” exists as a sop to the wounded pride of ‘artistes’ who never wrote anything anyone would want to read unless they were paid to do so. The Wheel of Time was so massively popular that, when Jordan finished the trilogy in the third book, the vast majority of his fans said “Lolwut? NO! Keep going, we’ll tell you when you can stop!” And, being a professional bestselling author rather than an artiste, he happily obliged…for the rest of his life. From a literary perspective, this kinda ruined the structure of the story and significantly undermined one of the major themes, especially when a different author was brought in to write the final book. But that’s okay. The original trilogy wasn’t effete, but it was art. But the literary world isn’t about art, it’s about wounded pride about nobody wanting to read what they write.
